docs.title: CodeGuard AI
docs.text:
AI-powered security scanner for your codebase

CodeGuard AI analyzes your source code for security vulnerabilities, best practice violations, and potential bugs using advanced AI models.

  • Get Started in 5 Minutes

    Install the CLI and scan your first project

    Quick Start

  • Security Analysis

    Understand how CodeGuard AI detects vulnerabilities

    How It Works

  • CLI Reference

    Complete reference for all CLI commands

    Commands

  • CI/CD Integration

    Add security scanning to your pipeline

    GitHub Actions

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• AI-Powered Analysis - Uses Claude AI to understand code context and detect real vulnerabilities
  • Multiple Languages - Supports 15+ programming languages including TypeScript, Python, Go, and more
  • Security Grades - Get A-F grades based on weighted severity scoring
  • CLI & Web Interface - Scan locally or through the web dashboard
  • CI/CD Ready - JSON output for easy integration with your pipeline

docs.title: Supported Languages
docs.text: Language Extensions JavaScript/TypeScript .js, .jsx, .ts, .tsx Python .py Go .go Java .java Ruby .rb PHP .php C/C++ .c, .cpp, .h, .hpp C# .cs Rust .rs Swift .swift Kotlin .kt, .kts Scala .scala Solidity .sol

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
# Install the CLI
go install github.com/codeguard-ai/cli@latest

# Scan your project
codeguard scan ./my-project

# Output as JSON for CI
codeguard scan --format json ./my-project

docs.title: Security Categories
docs.text:
CodeGuard AI checks for vulnerabilities across these categories:

  • Authentication & Authorization - Weak auth, session issues, access control
  • Input Validation - SQL injection, XSS, command injection, path traversal
  • Cryptography - Weak encryption, hardcoded secrets, insecure randomness
  • API Security - Missing rate limiting, data exposure
  • Error Handling - Information leakage, missing error handling
  • Configuration - Insecure defaults, debug mode, exposed endpoints

docs.title: Grading System
docs.text: CodeGuard AI assigns a letter grade (A-F) to provide a quick overview of your codebase's security posture.

docs.title: Grade Calculation
docs.text: Grades are calculated using a weighted scoring system:

docs.title: Severity Weights
docs.text: Severity Points Critical 10 High 5 Medium 2 Low 1

docs.title: Score Formula
docs.text: Score = (Critical × 10) + (High × 5) + (Medium × 2) + (Low × 1)

docs.title: Grade Thresholds
docs.text: Score Grade Description 0-5 A Excellent - Few or no issues 6-15 B Good - Minor issues only 16-30 C Fair - Some issues need attention 31-60 D Poor - Significant issues present 61+ F Critical - Immediate action required

docs.title: Grade A (Score: 0-5)
docs.text:
Critical: 0
High: 0
Medium: 2
Low: 1

Score = (0×10) + (0×5) + (2×2) + (1×1) = 5
Grade = A

docs.title: Grade C (Score: 16-30)
docs.text:
Critical: 1
High: 2
Medium: 3
Low: 4

Score = (1×10) + (2×5) + (3×2) + (4×1) = 30
Grade = C

docs.title: Grade F (Score: 61+)
docs.text:
Critical: 5
High: 3
Medium: 2
Low: 10

Score = (5×10) + (3×5) + (2×2) + (10×1) = 79
Grade = F

docs.title: Quick Wins
docs.text:
1. Fix Critical Issues First - Each critical issue removed improves score by 10 points
  2. Address High Severity - 5 points per high issue
  3. Batch Medium Fixes - Group related medium issues for efficient remediation

docs.title: Common Improvements
docs.text: Action Point Reduction Fix SQL injection -10 (critical) Add input validation -5 (high) Update weak crypto -5 (high) Add rate limiting -2 (medium) Add security headers -1 (low)

docs.title: Grade Trends
docs.text:
Track your grade over time to measure security improvements:

# Save scan results with timestamp
codeguard scan --format json > scan-$(date +%Y%m%d).json

The web dashboard shows grade history for each repository.

docs.title: CI/CD Grade Gates
docs.text:
Enforce minimum grades in your pipeline:

# GitHub Actions example
- name: Security Scan
  run: |
    RESULT=$(codeguard scan --format json)
    GRADE=$(echo $RESULT | jq -r '.grade')
    if [[ "$GRADE" == "D" || "$GRADE" == "F" ]]; then
      echo "Security grade $GRADE is below threshold"
      exit 1
    fi

docs.title: Understanding Your Grade
docs.text:
Grade What It Means Recommended Action A Excellent security posture Maintain current practices B Good with minor issues Fix issues during regular sprints C Needs attention Prioritize security work D Significant problems Create dedicated security sprint F Critical vulnerabilities Stop feature work, fix immediately

Context Matters

A "C" grade on an internal tool may be acceptable, while a "B" on a public API might require improvement. Adjust your expectations based on risk profile.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text: CodeGuard AI uses advanced AI models to analyze your source code for security vulnerabilities and code quality issues.

docs.title: 1. File Collection
docs.text:
The scanner collects source files from your codebase:

  • Identifies files by extension (.ts, .py, .go, etc.)
  • Skips ignored directories (node_modules, .git, vendor)
  • Respects file size limits (default: 100KB per file)

docs.title: 2. AI Analysis
docs.text:
Files are sent to Claude AI with specialized security prompts:

  • Security Analysis - Authentication, input validation, cryptography
  • Reliability Analysis - Error handling, resource management, race conditions

The AI understands code context, not just patterns, enabling detection of:

  • Complex vulnerabilities that span multiple files
  • Logic flaws that simple scanners miss
  • Context-dependent security issues

docs.title: 3. Issue Generation
docs.text:
The AI generates structured issues with:

  • Severity - Critical, High, Medium, Low
  • Category - Security, Input Validation, etc.
  • Location - File path and line numbers
  • Description - What the issue is
  • Remediation - How to fix it

docs.title: 4. Grading
docs.text:
A weighted score determines the overall grade:

Severity Points Critical 10 High 5 Medium 2 Low 1 Score Grade 0-5 A 6-15 B 16-30 C 31-60 D 61+ F

docs.title: AI vs Traditional Scanners
docs.text: Feature CodeGuard AI Traditional SAST Detection Method Understands code semantics Pattern matching False Positives Low (context-aware) High (rule-based) Custom Logic Catches business logic flaws Limited to known patterns Setup Zero configuration Extensive rule configuration Language Support Universal (AI understands all) Per-language rules

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
• Code Privacy - Files are sent to the API for analysis
  • Data Retention - Results are stored in your account
  • API Security - All communication is encrypted (HTTPS)

For sensitive codebases, consider:

  • Self-hosting the backend
  • Using the CLI with local-only mode (coming soon)

docs.title: Security Analysis
docs.text: CodeGuard AI performs comprehensive security analysis across multiple categories.

docs.title: Authentication & Authorization
docs.text:
Detects issues with user authentication and access control:

  • Weak or missing authentication
  • Insecure session management
  • Authorization bypass vulnerabilities
  • Insufficient access controls
  • Hardcoded credentials

Example Detection:

# Detected: Hardcoded credentials
def connect_to_database():
    password = "admin123"  # CRITICAL: Hardcoded password
    return db.connect(user="admin", password=password)

docs.title: Input Validation
docs.text:
Identifies injection and input handling vulnerabilities:

  • SQL/NoSQL injection
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
  • Command injection
  • Path traversal
  • LDAP/XML injection

Example Detection:

// Detected: SQL Injection
app.get('/user', (req, res) => {
  const query = `SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = ${req.params.id}`; // HIGH: SQL injection
  db.query(query);
});

docs.title: Cryptography
docs.text:
Finds cryptographic weaknesses:

  • Weak encryption algorithms (MD5, SHA1, DES)
  • Hardcoded secrets and API keys
  • Insecure random number generation
  • Missing encryption for sensitive data

Example Detection:

# Detected: Weak hashing algorithm
import hashlib

def hash_password(password):
    return hashlib.md5(password.encode()).hexdigest()  # HIGH: MD5 is cryptographically weak

docs.title: API Security
docs.text:
Identifies API endpoint vulnerabilities:

  • Missing rate limiting
  • Excessive data exposure
  • Insecure direct object references
  • Missing input validation

Example Detection:

// Detected: Missing rate limiting
app.post('/login', async (req, res) => {
  // MEDIUM: No rate limiting on authentication endpoint
  const { email, password } = req.body;
  const user = await authenticate(email, password);
});

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Detects error handling issues:

  • Information leakage through error messages
  • Missing error handling
  • Insecure logging of sensitive data

Example Detection:

// Detected: Information leakage
app.use((err, req, res, next) => {
  res.status(500).json({
    error: err.message,
    stack: err.stack  // HIGH: Stack trace exposed to client
  });
});

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Finds configuration security issues:

  • Debug mode in production
  • Insecure default configurations
  • Exposed sensitive endpoints
  • Missing security headers

Example Detection:

# Detected: Debug mode enabled
app = Flask(__name__)
app.config['DEBUG'] = True  # MEDIUM: Debug mode should be disabled in production

docs.title: JavaScript/TypeScript
docs.text:
• eval() and Function() usage
  • Prototype pollution
  • DOM-based XSS
  • Insecure innerHTML usage

docs.title: Python
docs.text:
• pickle deserialization
  • exec() and eval() usage
  • Unsafe YAML loading
  • SQL injection in ORMs

docs.title: Go
docs.text:
• Unchecked errors
  • Race conditions
  • Unsafe pointer usage
  • Hardcoded TLS configurations

docs.title: Java
docs.text:
• Deserialization vulnerabilities
  • XXE in XML parsers
  • LDAP injection
  • Insecure reflection

docs.title: Custom Rules
docs.text:
CodeGuard AI adapts its analysis based on:

  • Framework detection (Express, Django, Spring)
  • Configuration files (package.json, requirements.txt)
  • Project structure and patterns

This enables accurate detection of framework-specific vulnerabilities.

docs.title: Severity Levels
docs.text: CodeGuard AI categorizes issues into four severity levels based on exploitability and potential impact.

docs.title: Critical
docs.text:
Critical

Vulnerabilities that can be easily exploited and lead to significant damage.

Characteristics:

  • Easily exploitable with public tools/techniques
  • Can lead to complete system compromise
  • No authentication required to exploit
  • High business impact

Examples:

  • Remote Code Execution (RCE)
  • SQL injection allowing data extraction
  • Authentication bypass
  • Hardcoded admin credentials
  • Unauthenticated API with sensitive operations

Remediation Priority: Immediate - Fix before deploying to production

docs.title: High
docs.text:
High

Serious vulnerabilities requiring immediate attention.

Characteristics:

  • Exploitable with some effort
  • Can lead to significant data exposure
  • May require specific conditions
  • Moderate to high business impact

Examples:

  • Stored XSS vulnerabilities
  • CSRF on sensitive actions
  • Sensitive data exposure in logs
  • Insecure direct object references
  • Missing authentication on endpoints

Remediation Priority: Within 24-48 hours

docs.title: Medium
docs.text:
Medium

Vulnerabilities that require specific conditions to exploit.

Characteristics:

  • Requires specific conditions or insider access
  • Limited impact if exploited
  • May be defense-in-depth issues
  • Low to moderate business impact

Examples:

  • Reflected XSS
  • Weak cryptographic algorithms
  • Missing rate limiting
  • Verbose error messages
  • Session fixation

Remediation Priority: Within 1-2 weeks

docs.title: Low
docs.text:
Low

Best practice violations or minor issues.

Characteristics:

  • Difficult to exploit
  • Minimal impact
  • Informational findings
  • Code quality improvements

Examples:

  • Missing security headers
  • Information disclosure (version numbers)
  • Deprecated function usage
  • Commented-out code with credentials
  • Missing input validation (non-security)

Remediation Priority: During regular maintenance

docs.title: Severity in Context
docs.text:
The same vulnerability type may have different severities based on context:

Vulnerability Public API Internal Tool Admin Panel SQL Injection Critical High High Missing Auth Critical Medium High XSS High Medium Low Verbose Errors Medium Low Low

CodeGuard AI considers context when assigning severity, but you should adjust based on your specific risk tolerance and deployment environment.

docs.title: CLI
docs.text:
Show all issues including low severity:

codeguard scan --all

By default, low severity issues are hidden to reduce noise.

docs.title: CI/CD
docs.text:
Fail the build only on critical/high issues:

codeguard scan --format json | jq '.issues | map(select(.severity == "critical" or .severity == "high")) | length'

docs.title: SQL Injection
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

func GetUser(id string) (*User, error) {
    query := fmt.Sprintf("SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = '%s'", id)
    row := db.QueryRow(query)
    // ...
}

Fixed: 

func GetUser(id string) (*User, error) {
    query := "SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = $1"
    row := db.QueryRow(query, id)
    // ...
}

docs.title: Unchecked Errors
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

func ProcessFile(path string) {
    file, _ := os.Open(path)  // Error ignored!
    defer file.Close()
    // ...
}

Fixed: 

func ProcessFile(path string) error {
    file, err := os.Open(path)
    if err != nil {
        return fmt.Errorf("failed to open file: %w", err)
    }
    defer file.Close()
    // ...
    return nil
}

docs.title: Hardcoded Secrets
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

var jwtSecret = []byte("my-secret-key")

func GenerateToken(userID string) (string, error) {
    token := jwt.New(jwt.SigningMethodHS256)
    return token.SignedString(jwtSecret)
}

Fixed: 

var jwtSecret = []byte(os.Getenv("JWT_SECRET"))

func GenerateToken(userID string) (string, error) {
    if len(jwtSecret) == 0 {
        return "", errors.New("JWT_SECRET not configured")
    }
    token := jwt.New(jwt.SigningMethodHS256)
    return token.SignedString(jwtSecret)
}

docs.title: Race Conditions
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

var counter int

func IncrementCounter() {
    counter++  // Race condition!
}

Fixed: 

var (
    counter int
    mu      sync.Mutex
)

func IncrementCounter() {
    mu.Lock()
    defer mu.Unlock()
    counter++
}

// Or use atomic
var counter int64

func IncrementCounter() {
    atomic.AddInt64(&counter, 1)
}

docs.title: CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
# .github/workflows/security.yml
name: Security Scan

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  scan:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.22'

      - run: go install github.com/codeguard-ai/cli@latest

      - name: Scan
        env:
          CODEGUARD_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CODEGUARD_API_KEY }}
        run: |
          codeguard scan --format json > results.json
          GRADE=$(cat results.json | jq -r '.grade')
          echo "Security Grade: $GRADE"
          if [[ "$GRADE" == "D" || "$GRADE" == "F" ]]; then
            exit 1
          fi

docs.text:
.PHONY: security lint test

security:
    codeguard scan

security-ci:
    codeguard scan --format json > security-report.json

# Combine with other checks
check: lint test security

docs.title: SQL Injection
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

const user = await db.query(
  `SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = ${req.params.id}`
);

Fixed: 

const user = await db.query(
  'SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = $1',
  [req.params.id]
);

docs.title: Missing Rate Limiting
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

app.post('/login', async (req, res) => {
  // No rate limiting
  const { email, password } = req.body;
  // ...
});

Fixed: 

import rateLimit from 'express-rate-limit';

const loginLimiter = rateLimit({
  windowMs: 15 * 60 * 1000,
  max: 5,
  message: 'Too many login attempts'
});

app.post('/login', loginLimiter, async (req, res) => {
  // ...
});

docs.title: XSS via innerHTML
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

res.send(`<div>${userInput}</div>`);

Fixed: 

import { escape } from 'html-escaper';

res.send(`<div>${escape(userInput)}</div>`);

docs.title: SQL Injection
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

def get_user(user_id):
    cursor.execute(f"SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = {user_id}")

Fixed: 

def get_user(user_id):
    cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = %s", [user_id])

# Or with Django ORM
User.objects.get(id=user_id)

docs.title: Unsafe Deserialization
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

import pickle

def load_data(data):
    return pickle.loads(data)  # Arbitrary code execution!

Fixed: 

import json

def load_data(data):
    return json.loads(data)  # Safe

docs.title: Weak Cryptography
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

import hashlib

def hash_password(password):
    return hashlib.md5(password.encode()).hexdigest()

Fixed: 

from passlib.hash import argon2

def hash_password(password):
    return argon2.hash(password)

docs.title: Hardcoded Secrets
docs.text:
Vulnerable: 

# settings.py
SECRET_KEY = 'my-super-secret-key-123'
DEBUG = True

Fixed: 

# settings.py
import os

SECRET_KEY = os.environ.get('DJANGO_SECRET_KEY')
DEBUG = os.environ.get('DEBUG', 'False') == 'True'

on: [push, pull_request]

    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:

      - uses: actions/setup-go@v5

docs.text: Integrate CodeGuard AI into your continuous integration pipeline.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
CodeGuard CLI supports CI/CD integration through:

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Generic CI example
- name: Install CodeGuard
  run: go install github.com/codeguard-ai/cli@latest

- name: Run Security Scan
  env:
    CODEGUARD_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CODEGUARD_API_KEY }}
  run: codeguard scan --format json > results.json

- name: Check Results
  run: |
    GRADE=$(cat results.json | jq -r '.grade')
    echo "Security Grade: $GRADE"
    if [[ "$GRADE" == "F" ]]; then
      exit 1
    fi

- name: Comment on PR

      | Low | ${results.issues.filter(i => i.severity === 'low').length} |

docs.title: Best Practices

  4. Review results before blocking - Avoid false positive frustration
  5. Run on PRs - Catch issues before merge

Create .github/workflows/security.yml:

name: Security Scan

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  scan:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.22'

      - name: Install CodeGuard
        run: go install github.com/codeguard-ai/cli@latest

      - name: Run Security Scan
        env:
          CODEGUARD_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CODEGUARD_API_KEY }}
        run: codeguard scan --format json > results.json

      - name: Upload Results
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:

docs.title: With Grade Gate
docs.text:
Fail the build if grade is below threshold:

name: Security Scan

on:
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  scan:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.22'

      - name: Install CodeGuard
        run: go install github.com/codeguard-ai/cli@latest

      - name: Run Security Scan
        env:
          CODEGUARD_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CODEGUARD_API_KEY }}
        run: |
          codeguard scan --format json > results.json

          GRADE=$(cat results.json | jq -r '.grade')
          echo "grade=$GRADE" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "Security Grade: $GRADE"

          if [[ "$GRADE" == "D" || "$GRADE" == "F" ]]; then
            echo "::error::Security grade $GRADE is below threshold"
            exit 1
          fi
        id: scan

      - name: Upload Results
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        if: always()
        with:
          name: security-report
          path: results.json

docs.title: PR Comment Integration
docs.text:
Post scan results as a PR comment:

name: Security Scan

on:
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

permissions:
  contents: read
  pull-requests: write

jobs:
  scan:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.22'

      - name: Install CodeGuard
        run: go install github.com/codeguard-ai/cli@latest

      - name: Run Security Scan
        env:
          CODEGUARD_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.CODEGUARD_API_KEY }}
        run: codeguard scan --format json > results.json

      - name: Post PR Comment
        uses: actions/github-script@v7
        with:
          script: |
            const fs = require('fs');
            const results = JSON.parse(fs.readFileSync('results.json', 'utf8'));

            const gradeEmoji = {
              'A': ':white_check_mark:',
              'B': ':large_blue_circle:',
              'C': ':yellow_circle:',
              'D': ':orange_circle:',
              'F': ':red_circle:'
            };

            const severityCounts = {
              critical: results.issues.filter(i => i.severity === 'critical').length,
              high: results.issues.filter(i => i.severity === 'high').length,
              medium: results.issues.filter(i => i.severity === 'medium').length,
              low: results.issues.filter(i => i.severity === 'low').length
            };

            let issuesList = '';
            if (results.issues.length > 0) {
              const topIssues = results.issues.slice(0, 5);
              issuesList = '\n### Top Issues\n\n' + topIssues.map(i =>
                `- **[${i.severity.toUpperCase()}]** ${i.title} - \`${i.file}:${i.line}\``
              ).join('\n');

              if (results.issues.length > 5) {
                issuesList += `\n\n*...and ${results.issues.length - 5} more*`;
              }
            }

            const body = `## ${gradeEmoji[results.grade]} Security Scan: Grade ${results.grade}

            | Metric | Value |
            |--------|-------|
            | Files Scanned | ${results.filesScanned} |
            | Total Issues | ${results.issueCount} |
            | Score | ${results.score} |

            ### Issues by Severity

            | Severity | Count |
            |----------|-------|
            | :red_circle: Critical | ${severityCounts.critical} |
            | :orange_circle: High | ${severityCounts.high} |
            | :yellow_circle: Medium | ${severityCounts.medium} |
            | :white_circle: Low | ${severityCounts.low} |
            ${issuesList}

            ---
            *Powered by [CodeGuard AI](https://codeguard-ai.vercel.app)*`;

            github.rest.issues.createComment({
              owner: context.repo.owner,
              repo: context.repo.repo,
              issue_number: context.issue.number,
              body
            });

name: Scheduled Security Scan

on:
  schedule:

docs.title: Self-Hosted Deployment
docs.text: Deploy CodeGuard AI on your own infrastructure.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Node.js 20+
  • PostgreSQL 15+
  • Anthropic API key
  • Docker (optional, recommended)

docs.title: Using Docker Compose
docs.text:
# docker-compose.yml
version: '3.8'

services:
  frontend:
    build:
      context: ./packages/frontend
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    environment:
      - VITE_API_URL=http://backend:3001
    depends_on:
      - backend

  backend:
    build:
      context: ./packages/backend
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
    ports:
      - "3001:3001"
    environment:
      - DATABASE_URL=postgresql://codeguard:codeguard@db:5432/codeguard
      - ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=${ANTHROPIC_API_KEY}
    depends_on:
      - db

  db:
    image: postgres:15-alpine
    environment:
      - POSTGRES_USER=codeguard
      - POSTGRES_PASSWORD=codeguard
      - POSTGRES_DB=codeguard
    volumes:
      - pgdata:/var/lib/postgresql/data

volumes:
  pgdata:

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name codeguard.yourdomain.com;

    # Frontend
    location / {
        root /var/www/codeguard/frontend;
        try_files $uri $uri/ /index.html;

    # Backend API
    location /api {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:3001;
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection 'upgrade';
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_cache_bypass $http_upgrade;

docs.title: Sharing Repository Results
docs.text: Share your security analysis results with anyone using public share links.

docs.title: Creating a Share Link
docs.text:
1. Navigate to any repository in your dashboard
  2. Click the Share button in the header
  3. Choose an expiration time (optional):
  4. Never - Link never expires
  5. 1 day - Expires in 24 hours
  6. 7 days - Expires in one week
  7. 30 days - Expires in one month
  8. Click Create Link
  9. Copy the generated URL

docs.title: What's Included
docs.text:
The public share page shows:

  • Repository name and security grade
  • Issue counts by severity (Critical, High, Medium, Low)
  • Full file tree with issue indicators
  • Code viewer with syntax highlighting
  • Detailed issue information including:
  • Description
  • Affected line numbers
  • Remediation suggestions

docs.title: Managing Share Links
docs.text:
View and manage all share links for a repository:

  1. Click the Share button on any repository
  2. See all active share links with their:
  3. Creation date
  4. Expiration date (if set)
  5. Link URL
  6. Click the trash icon to revoke any share link

Revoking Links

Revoking a share link immediately invalidates it. Anyone with the old URL will no longer be able to access the results.

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
• Share links are read-only - viewers cannot modify anything
  • Links use secure random tokens (32 hex characters)
  • No authentication required to view shared results
  • Consider using expiring links for sensitive codebases
  • You can revoke links at any time

docs.title: Workspaces & Team Management
docs.text: Organize your repositories and collaborate with your team using workspaces.

docs.title: What are Workspaces?
docs.text:
Workspaces are isolated containers for your repositories. Each workspace has:

  • Its own set of repositories
  • Separate API tokens
  • Team members with different roles
  • Independent settings

docs.title: Creating a Workspace
docs.text:
1. Click your profile avatar in the top-right corner
  2. Under Workspaces, click Create workspace
  3. Type a name and press Enter

The new workspace becomes active immediately.

docs.title: Switching Workspaces
docs.text:
1. Click your profile avatar
  2. Click any workspace in the list
  3. The page reloads with that workspace's repositories

Your selection is remembered across sessions.

docs.title: Team Roles
docs.text:
Workspaces support four roles with different permissions:

Role View Repos Add/Delete Repos Manage Members Delete Workspace Viewer Yes No No No Member Yes Yes No No Admin Yes Yes Yes No Owner Yes Yes Yes Yes

docs.title: Inviting Team Members
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > Members tab
  2. Enter the person's email address
  3. Select their role (Viewer, Member, or Admin)
  4. Click Send Invite

The invitee receives an email with a link to join. Invitations expire after 7 days.

docs.title: Changing Roles
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > Members
  2. Find the member in the list
  3. Click the role dropdown
  4. Select the new role

Role Restrictions

  • Only owners can change admin roles
  • Owners cannot be demoted (transfer ownership first)

docs.title: Removing Members
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > Members
  2. Click the remove button next to the member
  3. Confirm the removal

docs.title: Canceling Invitations
docs.text: Pending invitations appear in the Pending Invites section. Click the X to cancel.

docs.title: Renaming a Workspace
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > General
  2. Edit the workspace name
  3. Click Save Changes

docs.title: Deleting a Workspace
docs.text:
This is permanent

Deleting a workspace removes all its repositories and data. This cannot be undone.

  1. Go to Settings > General
  2. Click Delete Workspace
  3. Type the workspace name to confirm
  4. Click Delete Workspace

docs.title: Leaving a Workspace (Non-Owners)
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > General
  2. Click Leave Workspace
  3. Confirm your choice

docs.title: For Teams
docs.text:
• Create separate workspaces for different projects or clients
  • Use the Admin role for team leads who need to manage members
  • Use Member for developers who need to add and scan repositories
  • Use Viewer for stakeholders who only need to see results

docs.title: For Personal Use
docs.text:
• Your default workspace is created automatically on signup
  • Create additional workspaces to separate personal and work projects

docs.title: MCP Server Integration
docs.text: CodeGuard AI provides a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that allows you to integrate security scanning capabilities directly into AI-powered development tools like Claude Desktop, Cursor, and other MCP-compatible clients.

docs.title: What is MCP?
docs.text:
The Model Context Protocol is an open protocol that enables AI assistants to interact with external tools and data sources. By connecting CodeGuard AI as an MCP server, you can:

  • Scan code snippets for vulnerabilities directly from your AI assistant
  • Query your repository's security issues
  • Get real-time security analysis while coding

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, you'll need:

  1. A CodeGuard AI account with at least one workspace
  2. An API token (create one in Settings)
  3. An MCP-compatible client (Claude Desktop, Cursor, etc.)

docs.title: Creating an API Token
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings (click your profile picture, then "Settings")
  2. Under API Tokens, click Create Token
  3. Give your token a descriptive name (e.g., "Claude Desktop")
  4. Select the workspace you want to grant access to
  5. Choose an expiration period or select "Never expires"
  6. Click Create Token

Important

Copy your token immediately after creation. You won't be able to see it again!

docs.title: Server Configuration
docs.text:
The MCP server is available at:

https://security-guard-ai.vercel.app/api/mcp

Or if running locally:

http://localhost:3001/api/mcp

docs.title: Setting Up Claude Desktop
docs.text:
Add the following to your Claude Desktop configuration file:

macOSWindows

Edit ~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json

Edit %APPDATA%\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "codeguard-ai": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@anthropic-ai/mcp-remote", "https://security-guard-ai.vercel.app/api/mcp"],
      "env": {
        "MCP_HEADERS": "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_TOKEN_HERE"
      }
    }
  }
}

Replace YOUR_API_TOKEN_HERE with your actual API token.

docs.title: Setting Up Cursor
docs.text:
In Cursor, you can add the MCP server through the settings:

  1. Open Cursor Settings
  2. Navigate to Features > MCP Servers
  3. Add a new server with:
  4. Name: CodeGuard AI
  5. URL: https://security-guard-ai.vercel.app/api/mcp
  6. Headers: Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_TOKEN

docs.title: Available Tools
docs.text: The MCP server provides the following tools:

docs.title: scan_code
docs.text:
Analyze code for security vulnerabilities and code quality issues.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description code string Yes The source code to analyze language string Yes Programming language (javascript, python, java, go, rust, typescript) filename string No Optional filename for context

Example:

{
  "name": "scan_code",
  "arguments": {
    "code": "const query = `SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = ${userId}`",
    "language": "javascript",
    "filename": "database.js"
  }
}

Response:

{
  "issues": [
    {
      "id": "SEC-001",
      "severity": "critical",
      "category": "Security",
      "title": "SQL Injection Vulnerability",
      "description": "User input is directly interpolated into SQL query without sanitization",
      "lineStart": 1,
      "lineEnd": 1,
      "suggestion": "Use parameterized queries or an ORM to prevent SQL injection"
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: list_repositories
docs.text:
List all repositories in your workspace that have been analyzed.

Parameters: None

Response:

{
  "repositories": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "name": "my-app",
      "owner": "username",
      "status": "completed",
      "createdAt": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: get_repository_issues
docs.text:
Get security issues for a specific repository.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description repositoryId number Yes The repository ID severity string No Filter by severity (critical, high, medium, low)

Response:

{
  "repository": {
    "id": 1,
    "name": "my-app",
    "owner": "username"
  },
  "issues": [...],
  "total": 15
}

docs.title: Example Usage
docs.text:
Once configured, you can ask Claude or your AI assistant:

"Scan this code for security issues: [paste code]"

"What security vulnerabilities were found in my-app repository?"

"List all my analyzed repositories"

The AI will use the MCP tools to fetch real-time data from CodeGuard AI.

docs.title: Protocol Details
docs.text: The MCP server implements JSON-RPC 2.0 over HTTP POST. All requests require Bearer token authentication.

docs.title: Supported Methods
docs.text: Method Description initialize Initialize the MCP connection tools/list List available tools tools/call Execute a tool ping Health check

docs.title: Example Request
docs.text:
curl -X POST https://security-guard-ai.vercel.app/api/mcp \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer cg_your_token_here" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "jsonrpc": "2.0",
    "id": 1,
    "method": "tools/list",
    "params": {}
  }'

docs.title: Token Not Working
docs.text:
• Ensure your token hasn't expired
  • Verify the token has access to the workspace you're trying to query
  • Check that the Authorization header is formatted correctly: Bearer <token>

docs.title: Connection Errors
docs.text:
• Verify the server URL is correct
  • Check your network connection
  • Ensure your firewall allows outgoing connections to the API

docs.title: No Repositories Found
docs.text:
• Confirm you've analyzed at least one repository in the workspace
  • Verify your token is associated with the correct workspace

docs.title: Rate Limits
docs.text:
API tokens are subject to the following rate limits:

  • Code scanning: 100 requests per minute
  • Repository queries: 1000 requests per minute

If you exceed these limits, you'll receive a 429 Too Many Requests response.

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Rotate tokens regularly: Create new tokens periodically and revoke old ones
  2. Use expiring tokens: Set an expiration date when possible
  3. Limit scope: Create separate tokens for different use cases
  4. Never commit tokens: Add .env files to .gitignore
  5. Monitor usage: Check the "Last used" date in Settings to detect unauthorized use

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
The CLI stores configuration in ~/.codeguard.json:

{
  "api_url": "https://codeguard-ai.vercel.app/api",
  "api_key": "your-api-key",
  "team_id": "optional-team-id"
}

docs.title: Fields
docs.text: Field Type Description Required api_url string API endpoint URL No (has default) api_key string Authentication key Yes team_id string Team identifier No

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Override configuration with environment variables:

Variable Description Priority CODEGUARD_API_KEY API key Highest CODEGUARD_API_URL API endpoint Highest CODEGUARD_CONFIG Config file path Highest

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Use environment variable for CI/CD
export CODEGUARD_API_KEY="${{ secrets.CODEGUARD_API_KEY }}"
codeguard scan

docs.title: Supported Extensions
docs.text:
The scanner automatically detects these file types:

.js, .jsx, .ts, .tsx    # JavaScript/TypeScript
.py                      # Python
.go                      # Go
.java                    # Java
.rb                      # Ruby
.php                     # PHP
.c, .cpp, .h, .hpp      # C/C++
.cs                      # C#
.rs                      # Rust
.swift                   # Swift
.kt, .kts               # Kotlin
.scala                   # Scala
.sol                     # Solidity

docs.title: Ignored Directories
docs.text:
These directories are automatically skipped:

node_modules/
vendor/
.git/
.svn/
dist/
build/
target/
__pycache__/
.venv/
venv/
.idea/
.vscode/
coverage/
.next/
.nuxt/

docs.title: File Size Limits
docs.text:
• Default max file size: 100KB
  • Files larger than this are skipped

docs.title: Using a Different Config File
docs.text: codeguard --config /path/to/config.json scan

docs.title: Self-Hosted API
docs.text:
For self-hosted instances, update the API URL:

# Edit config
cat > ~/.codeguard.json << EOF
{
  "api_url": "https://your-instance.com/api",
  "api_key": "your-key"
}
EOF

Or use environment variable:

export CODEGUARD_API_URL="https://your-instance.com/api"
codeguard scan

docs.title: Credential Storage
docs.text:
• API keys are stored in plaintext in the config file
  • File permissions are set to 0600 (owner read/write only)
  • Consider using environment variables in CI/CD

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Never commit .codeguard.json to version control
  2. Add to .gitignore: 
    ~/.codeguard.json
  3. Use environment variables in CI/CD pipelines
  4. Rotate API keys periodically

docs.title: CLI Overview
docs.text: The CodeGuard CLI is a command-line tool for scanning your codebase for security vulnerabilities.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Fast Scanning - Async analysis with status polling
  • Multiple Formats - Pretty output for humans, JSON for CI/CD
  • Offline Detection - Scans locally, sends to API for analysis
  • Smart Filtering - Ignores build artifacts, dependencies, etc.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
go install github.com/codeguard-ai/cli@latest

Or download from releases.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
# Scan current directory
codeguard scan

# Scan specific path
codeguard scan ./src

# JSON output
codeguard scan --format json

# Show all issues including low severity
codeguard scan --all

docs.title: Command Structure
docs.text: codeguard <command> [subcommand] [flags]
